material.mattext: Assuming that shoppers enter the store through the two doors independently, what is σ<font size="8">T</font>, the standard deviation of T?

Incorrect. It seems like you are adding σ<font size="9">X</font> and σ<font size="9">Y</font> which is wrong. Note that the rule says that if X and Y are two independent random variables then: σ²<font size="9">X+Y</font> = σ²<font size="9">X</font> + σ²<font size="9">Y</font>, and then to find the standard deviation of X+Y, you'll take the square root.

Incorrect. You are using the right rule, σ²<font size="9">X+Y</font> = σ²<font size="9">X</font> + σ²<font size="9">Y</font>, which gives you the variance of T. Note, however that we are asking you to find the standard deviation of T.

Incorrect. It seems like you are adding the two standard deviations and then taking a square root of that, which is wrong. Note that the rule says that if X and Y are two independent random variables then: σ²<font size="9">X+Y</font> = σ²<font size="9">X</font> + σ²<font size="9">Y</font>, and then to find the standard deviation of X+Y, you'll take the square root.

Good Job! Indeed, since X and Y are independent: σ²<font size="9">T</font> = σ²<font size="9">X+Y</font> = σ²<font size="9">X</font> + σ²<font size="9">Y</font> = 25 + 64 = 89. Therefore σ<font size="8">T</font> is the square root of 89.
